data.text: - Ability to be able to stop somewhere (e.g. an attraction, shops, restaurant etc) and take your bags off you bike and take them with you to keep your gear safe while you lock up your bike. - Length of self support tour that you can go on (e.g. days vs. weeks vs. months) - Amount of spares or water you can take when going in territory where parts or water isnâ€™t available. - Off road ability - MTBing - â€˜Comfortâ€™ ability to have a larger tent or take a few more things.

data.text: Bikepacking- ultralight, less comfortable but lighter n faster Touring- heavier but a lot more comfortable and less secluded usually Just my opinion!

data.text: I would sugest that your set up should be a result of the where you want to go, how far / fast and how much comfort. After that its all just equipment
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: it depends, on you....think of what youalready know.....ask the same question with an auto in mind, and see what you come up with....
data.author: Philip Buckley

data.text: Bike packing is the newer market where lighter pricier and minimal gear is optimized for climbing (think Hike a Bike). Touring is staying mostly paved w greater load capacity both weight and volume of gear. While both can be considered touring, I think of traditional touring as "hitting the road where as bikepacking is " off the Beaten trail" Now these are marketing terms that can interchange. I took a pair of rear panniers w older not really light gear where my friend took the newer lighter stuff. I was wasted on climbing. But I could carry more water if I chose. Also took change of night clothes for comfort where he slept in what he rode in (I couldn't do that). It's trade offs. Ask yourself what do u need and do a trial run of where u want to visit/stay. Maybe u decide neither is for you lol.
data.author: Topher Nando

data.text: I saw an interesting YouTube video about bike weight , The biggest difference is your body weight ,the weight of the bike at the most is 1 % difference ,unless you have to lift it over gates etc , I have one bike that weight 17kg & can carry over 70 kg of stuff & - another bike at 12kg ,I've tested them over the same routes & there is very little difference on the times ,
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: Itâ€™s really boils down to volume and clearance. Hard to get more than 40 liters of storage on a bikepacking setup without wearing a pack or having weird stuff strapped on. Easy to have double that volume with panniers. Single trackâ€¦ gotta go light and streamlined.
data.author: Brandon G Lampley

data.text: bikepacking bags are way more arrow dynamic
data.author: Tdogg Tdogg

data.text: Bikepacking bags are way cooler especially those seat bag that looks like a half chub wagging behind you. Low riding panniers are great for a lower center of gravity that improves handling but the get caught on stuff riding single-track. I like a carridice style bag out back with a basket or Rando bag up front. Sometimes I roll with two carridice style bags. With a frame bag stuffed full of food and water I can usually fit all my other stuff in two bags.
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: It depends on what bike and equipment you have. Credit card touring and randonneuring are very lightweight, and randonneurring goes for very long distances, whereas adventure touring remote parts of the world is off-road and you can stop wherever you want, because you've carried all your food and gear to camp with you and that can be heavy or lightweight. For purists, bikepacking doesn't use racks, but the bags become so large they need internal supports and cages 9But, don't call them racks.). Frame bags have been around for a long time. Tailfin's bikepacking rack is just a rack that allows for rear suspension travel, because some people want to carry more than a traditional bikepacking setup. When I first saw bikepacking videos and articles, I thought bikepacking was called that because nearly all riders had on small daypacks for the gear they couldn't fit into their bags. Since then, the only real difference I've seen is bikepacking doesn't use low rider front bags, because the bags are close enough to the obstacles (logs, rocks etc.) to get caught on them. However, adventure touring and world touring uses low rider bags under very similar conditions and seem to do fine. And then there is the subject of trailers... To me bike touring, randonneuring and bikepacking, among others, are on a 3-D continuum/cone and is influenced by your bike, physical abilities and what you want to take. The Buffalo Soldiers rode heavy single speed bikes throughout the western US under "bikepacking" conditions. The best set up when starting out is the one you are closest to having right now. You can fine tune what you like and don't like from the different bicycling disciples, just keep an open mind on what you can to use. I got ridiculed for using panniers and rear rack on a hardtail on a trip with "bikepackers" with rear suspension bikes, but a saddlebag on my bike seemed stupid.

data.text: I am not in it for a suffer-fest while pedaling long uphill grades. I want to enjoy the ride. I try to pack as light as possible without being foolish. I keep my body weight low as well.
data.author: Joseph Koziol

data.text: if I go through the mountainous West there is little route planning can do to avoid punishing climbs
data.author: Joseph Koziol

data.text: Ive tried both and prefer the bikepacking bags more. They are easier to get on and off the bike, they limit the amount of equipment you carry to the essentials, and this leads to an overall more agile and nimble bike compared to a touring setup. I use revelate designs bags and can fit about 35-40L of volume total. I decided to sell my touring bike and try a hard tail mountain bike. I was able to fit larger tires and get off road on to trails with all my equipment stable, centered in the frame pack to lower the center of mass. I even biked through squamish trails with my rig
data.author: Diego Alvarado

data.text: I do both. Depends where I want to go, how long for and what I want to take.

data.text: A lot of people are talking about weight management. You can buy panniers that are fairly small. My back panniers carry around 40 liters and work for a few week long trips. The main advantage with panniers is they are easy to get on and off the bike.
data.author: Chris Hayworth

data.text: It all depends on your bike ,how long you will be touring...I have a Touring Bike, the Trek 520, designed as a touring bike. I use Panniers or I pull a trailer....Bikepacking is too minimalistic for me...I like my creature comforts...
data.author: Martin Fano

data.text: Serious cycle tourists (those who tour for more than a few days) secretly laugh at the current bike packing trend. Invest in a good touring bike and buy a rack and a decent set of panniers, if your goal is actually to spend time exploring parts of the world on a bike, rather than poncing around on a few overnight trips and hoping you look cool. Touring is not about speed, itâ€™s about endurance. If you want speed, drop the packs all together and buy yourself a skinny tyred road bike and race around every Sunday morning with all the other mediocre Gino Bartali wanna bees
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: each to their own. Youâ€™re not a serious cyclist if you ridicule others for how they choose to ride. The important thing is that everyone gets out on their bikes and enjoy themselves in their own way, whether it be touring, bikepacking, road, mtb or any other form of cycling
